item.title: Trump Issues M.L.K. Day Proclamation After Criticism
item.description: Civil rights groups had criticized President Trump for failing to issue a proclamation honoring Martin Luther King Jr. and not attending commemorative events.
item.dc:creator: Francesca Regalado
item.category: National Assn for the Advancement of Colored People
item.media:credit: Allison Robbert for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Trump at the College Football Championship in Miami on Monday.

item.title: Judge Allows Policy Restricting Lawmakers’ Access to ICE Facilities
item.description: The decision permitted the Trump administration to continue restricting inspections of the conditions inside immigration detention compounds.
item.dc:creator: Zach Montague
item.media:credit: Jamie Kelter Davis for The New York Times
item.media:description: Representative Delia Ramirez, Democrat of Illinois, during an unannounced oversight visit to the Broadview Processing Center in Broadview, Ill., last June.

item.title: Treatment for Transgender Teens in Colorado Begin to Disappear Under Trump
item.description: The Trump administration has used an array of pressure tactics to try to end treatments for minors, even in states that want to keep them.
item.dc:creator: Amy Harmon and Adam Perez
item.media:credit: Adam Perez for The New York Times

item.title: Before Trump, Greensboro, Vermont Was a Foodie Mecca for Canadians
item.description: Greensboro’s economy depended on friendly relations with Canada. But after tariffs and threats to make the country the “51st state,” neighborly ties have frayed.
item.dc:creator: Jenna Russell and Lily Landes
item.media:description: Willey’s Store has long attracted customers from Canada.

item.title: Cubans in Florida Are Being Deported in Record Numbers
item.description: Cubans had long benefited from legal privileges unavailable to immigrants from other countries. President Trump has changed that.
item.dc:creator: Patricia Mazzei
item.media:credit: Alfonso Duran for The New York Times
item.media:description: Some Floridians worry that these deportations could stain the state’s proud Cuban identity.

item.title: How Trump Made Life Difficult for International Students and Wisconsin
item.description: Last fall, the number of new international undergraduates fell by 25 percent compared to the previous year. That drop poses financial and competitive challenges.
item.dc:creator: Amy Qin and Jamie Kelter Davis
item.media:description: The University of Wisconsin-Madison has around 8,000 students, 15 percent of its enrollment, that are from abroad.

item.title: At a Seattle Port Rocked by Tariffs, There Were 70 Jobs for 600 Workers
item.description: Dock workers are used to uncertainty, but nothing since the Great Recession of 2008 compares to what they have experienced this year.
item.dc:creator: Anna Griffin and Ruth Fremson
item.media:description: Since August, the monthly drop in traffic has been in the double digits compared to 2024. There was no pre-Christmas rush.

item.title: Sister Norma Pimentel’s Shelter in McAllen, Texas Looks Different Now
item.description: Sister Pimentel’s shelter in McAllen, one of the poorest cities in America, pivoted to feed the hungry.
item.dc:creator: Edgar Sandoval and Gabriel V. Cárdenas
item.media:description: “We have not seen a single migrant in months,” Sister Norma Pimentel said last month. “We are completely empty.”

item.title: Middle Tennessee State University Dean Laura Sosh-Lightsy Fired For Charlie Kirk Comments
item.description: Laura Sosh-Lightsy’s punishment reflects the new power dynamics in the free-speech debate, especially in red states.
item.dc:creator: Emily Cochrane
item.media:credit: Landon Edwards for The New York Times
item.media:description: Laura Sosh-Lightsy was fired from her job as a dean at Middle Tennessee State University after posting on Facebook.

item.title: Columbia University Protest Culture Is Tame Even in Anti-Trump New York
item.description: The Trump administration has pushed universities all over the country to act against student protesters.
item.dc:creator: Sharon Otterman and Marco Postigo Storel
item.media:description: Columbia was President Trump’s first high-profile university target, followed by Harvard, Brown, Northwestern and others

item.title: Twin Falls, Idaho Has New Residents: 37 Afrikaners
item.description: Twin Falls and its dairy industry have benefited from an influx of refugees from places like Bosnia, the Democratic Republic of Congo and Myanmar. That era is over.
item.dc:creator: Miriam Jordan and Loren Elliott
item.media:description: A service in Swahili at Twin Falls Church of the Nazarene.

item.title: Trump’s Cuts to the C.D.C. Also Hurt Atlanta
item.description: The earnest government disease fighter had become a kind of city archetype, alongside aspiring rappers and C-suite strivers. Now scientists are leaving.
item.dc:creator: Richard Fausset
item.category: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
item.media:credit: Dustin Chambers for The New York Times

item.title: At Yosemite National Park, Staffing Cuts Mean Visitors Have Gone Wild
item.description: After the Trump administration’s cuts, workers at the national park are spread too thin to stop people from littering, flying drones and cliff-diving.
item.dc:creator: Soumya Karlamangla and Angus Morton
item.media:credit: Angus Morton for The New York Times

item.title: Nome, Alaska Is Now Key to Trump’s Global Ambitions
item.description: Nome, population 3,700, is accessible only by plane outside a few months when boats can pass through. But it will be the home of the nation’s only deepwater Arctic port.
item.dc:creator: Anna Griffin and Ruth Fremson
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:description: Nome’s existing dock will be turned into the country’s first deepwater Arctic port.

item.title: Pastor Travis Johnson Credits Trump for Reviving Evangelicalism
item.description: The president has given a new class of evangelists direct access to the White House. In return, many support him without question.
item.dc:creator: Ruth Graham and Vincent Alban
item.media:description: Travis Johnson sees signs everywhere that the country is better off today than it was when President Trump took office a year ago.

item.title: Indiana Judge and His Wife Are Shot at Their Suburban Home
item.description: The police in Lafayette, Ind., said they were investigating the nonfatal shootings of a Tippecanoe County Superior Court judge and his wife on Sunday.
item.dc:creator: Stephanie Saul
item.media:credit: Ron Wilkins/Journal & Courier, via Imagn
item.media:description: Police officers outside the home of Judge Steven Meyer and his wife, Kim, in Lafayette, Ind., on Sunday.

item.title: Gaza’s Board of Peace: What to Know
item.description: Numerous countries say they have been invited to join President Trump’s newly minted organization, which critics say could undermine the United Nations.
item.dc:creator: Aaron Boxerman and Isabel Kershner
item.media:credit: Saher Alghorra for The New York Times
item.media:description: Gaza City in December.

item.title: Protest at Minnesota Church Service Adds to Tensions Over ICE Tactics
item.description: The Justice Department said it would investigate the protest over a pastor’s apparent role in immigration enforcement in the state.
item.dc:creator: Lauren McCarthy, Maia Coleman and Emily Cochrane
item.media:credit: Jamie Kelter Davis for The New York Times
item.media:description: Demonstrators outside the Bishop Henry Whipple Federal Building near Minneapolis on Sunday.

item.title: Trump Is Pushing the U.S.-Europe Alliance to the Brink Over Greenland
item.description: As President Trump tries to coerce European leaders over Greenland, they are pondering the unthinkable: Is an 80-year-old alliance doomed?
item.dc:creator: Michael D. Shear
item.media:credit: Doug Mills/The New York Times
item.media:description: President Trump with European leaders at the White House in August. On Saturday, Mr. Trump said he would raise tariffs on several European countries unless they let him acquire Greenland.

item.title: Powell Will Attend Supreme Court Hearing on Lisa Cook’s Lawsuit Against Trump
item.description: A lawsuit by the Fed governor Lisa D. Cook has challenged President Trump’s push to fire her.
item.dc:creator: Colby Smith
item.media:credit: Caroline Gutman for The New York Times
item.media:description: Jerome H. Powell, the chair of the Federal Reserve, will attend the arguments regarding Lisa Cook.

item.title: Federal Reserve Inquiry Clouds Trump’s Supreme Court Bid to Oust Lisa Cook
item.description: The court is set to hear Ms. Cook’s case challenging her firing as the Justice Department investigates Jerome H. Powell, the central bank chair.
item.dc:creator: Ann E. Marimow

item.title: Read the Texts Between Trump and Norway’s Prime Minister
item.description: In the exchange on Sunday, Norway’s leader sought to “de-escalate” the growing conflict over Greenland and Mr. Trump’s latest tariff threat.
item.dc:creator: Jeffrey Gettleman
item.media:credit: Hannah McKay/Reuters
item.media:description: President Trump texted Jonas Gahr Store, Norway’s leader, blaming his country for not awarding Mr. Trump the Nobel Peace Prize.

item.title: Elon Musk Spends $10 Million to Help Nate Morris in Kentucky Senate Race
item.description: Elon Musk, the world’s richest person, backed Nate Morris, a Republican businessman, in the primary race to succeed Senator Mitch McConnell in Kentucky.
item.dc:creator: Theodore Schleifer
item.media:credit: Haiyun Jiang/The New York Times
item.media:description: Elon Musk at the Kennedy Center in November. After his falling out with President Trump last year, he has inched back toward the Republican fold.

item.title: Trump’s Trade Negotiator Says Response to Court Loss Would Be Immediate
item.description: If the Supreme Court rules against its tariffs, the Trump administration would begin replacing them immediately, said Jamieson Greer, the United States Trade Representative.
item.dc:creator: Ana Swanson
item.media:credit: Haiyun Jiang/The New York Times
item.media:description: Jamieson Greer, the United States Trade Representative, on Air Force One in October.

item.title: Trump Links His Push for Greenland to Not Winning Nobel Peace Prize
item.description: In a text, President Trump told Norway’s prime minister that he no longer felt obliged to “think purely of Peace” and that the U.S. needed the island for global security.
item.dc:creator: Jeffrey Gettleman and Henrik Pryser Libell
item.media:credit: Haiyun Jiang for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Trump and Prime Minister Jonas Gahr Store of Norway during a meeting last year.

item.title: European Allies Mull Retaliation Over Trump’s Greenland Threats
item.description: Britain’s prime minister, alarmed by President Trump’s comments, said his country “must stand up for its values” after Mr. Trump threatened a new tariff war over acquiring the island.
item.dc:creator: Lizzie Dearden
item.media:credit: Pool photo by Jordan Pettitt
item.media:description: Prime Minister Keir Starmer of Britain speaking to the news media at Downing Street in London on Monday.

item.title: Trump Has an Offramp on Greenland. He Doesn’t Seem to Want It.
item.description: The strategic importance of Greenland is growing, and NATO has underinvested in Arctic security. But President Trump, intent on ownership, is rebuffing deals with Europe to solve the problem.
item.dc:creator: David E. Sanger
item.media:credit: Allison Robbert for The New York Times
item.media:description: For President Trump, the sheer size of Greenland’s territory holds part of the appeal; it is about three times the size of Texas, and bigger than Alaska.

item.title: Search of Reporter’s Home Tests Law With Roots in a Campus Paper’s Suit
item.description: The Stanford Daily lost a 1978 Supreme Court case over the search of its newsroom. But a bipartisan backlash prompted a federal law protecting journalists.
item.dc:creator: Adam Liptak
item.media:credit: Eric Lee/The New York Times
item.media:description: The search of the home of a Washington Post reporter last week may be another turning point in arguments over press freedom.

item.title: Texas Schools Wait as Law on Ten Commandments Reaches Appeals Court
item.description: A state law mandating the display of the Ten Commandments in every classroom has already divided Texas schools. Now a federal appeals court will decide its constitutionality.
item.dc:creator: Pooja Salhotra
item.media:credit: Desiree Rios for The New York Times
item.media:description: On Tuesday, the 17 active judges on the generally conservative Fifth Circuit Court of Appeals in New Orleans will hear arguments over the Texas state law mandating the display of the Ten Commandments.

item.title: ‘An Unbelievable Mess’: Artists Are Stymied by Trump Travel Bans
item.description: Musicians, theater groups and others from overseas are facing visa challenges and rising costs, posing a looming crisis for the performing arts sector.
item.dc:creator: Ben Sisario
item.media:credit: Douglas Mason/Getty Images
item.media:description: Tinariwen canceled an American tour when the Trump administration announced travel restrictions on 19 countries, including Mali, where most of its members are from.

item.title: I.M.F. Raises Forecast for Global Growth as Tariff Drag Fades
item.description: The 3.3 percent rate for 2026 would match last year’s pace. Booming investment in artificial intelligence is buttressing global output.
item.dc:creator: Alan Rappeport
item.media:credit: Eric Lee for The New York Times
item.media:description: An exhibit at a conference held by Nvidia, which makes chips that power artificial intelligence. Surging investment in technology is poised this year to offset the headwinds of rising protectionism.
